phrase.item: As far as I know, in my childhood in that village, I used to go a lot with my mother to the summer pastures. I would go with my mother...
My mother and our extended family and those people whose herds we would take-- we would go to the summer pasture, to the top of mountain.
And so starting in my childhood I got used to going to summer pasture [while living] in the village. I have seen nature very close up.
Leading a village life, but after that, because of school, [we students] would go down to the cities, and there was a great difference [there].
The reason for going there is to get an education. However, in the village the lifestyle is very natural. My early life was very beautiful.
Because of education... parents would always say, "Anywhere you go, [education] will always benefit you."
When I was around... I was in 7th grade, I started attending Aga Khan Diamond Jubilee School in the village.
Then in 7th grade I left the village and went to the city. My older brother had a management role there, and he guided me a lot toward studying. So then I came to the city.
​Press we did not have enough facilities, but we lived very happily.
In the morning, we used to go to [the primary] school, and after school we used to help our parents on the land.
We also [helped] with taking care of flocks [of sheep and goats] and herds of cows. We used to help them a lot.
Now those days are missed so much,
because we had a free and beautiful life back then. There weren't that many worries.
I went to the city to get an education, and after getting it I worked.
Life seems glamorous there [in the city], but it has difficulties as well.
After graduating from university and finishing all my studies, I went back [to the village] and worked for about ten years.
After that, our family, my family members, decided to come to America.
[My wife at the time] had a course [of study] here and so we came here to America.
Gojal consists of... In Gojal, the majority of the population consists of Wakhi speakers.
But in everyday life Wakhi speakers mix together with Burushaski speakers.
For the purpose of education, Wakhis go to Kunjut, and when they go to Hunza they interact with Burushaski people, so they understand the Burushaski language.
Down from there, there is another city called Gilgit.

Well, Gilgit is like New York, there are Shina speakers, Burushaski speakers are also there, Wakhis are also there, Chitrolis are also there, like that many [languages]. So those who come to Gilgit continue their education, they speak all these languages.
Most of people living in Gilgit are Shina speakers. It is in the center.
Then there are the Balti people who come from Baltistan.
Their language is also spoken there.

Before, all our brothers [from the community], including my family, when they went from one village to another for studies, when they came to the city from all those different villages, they became fluent in all the languages, spoke them well.

Likewise, my father and brother, they speak Wakhi, Burushaski, and Shina. Moving directly from the village, one loses [the chance to learn all the different languages], especially when just moving to any city of Pakistan. [Now] moving to the city directly [from a village] adults don't know other local languages.
For instance, I understand Shina and Burushaski but I cannot speak them.
The reason is that I moved from the village directly to the city.

I have lost that [opportunity], but even up until now those who study back there [in the village] and come from there directly down to the valley, they don't get the benefit of learning those languages, to understand or to speak them.
People who are living in Pakistan, including me, feel very happy going abroad.
So were we, we were very happy about coming to America.
When we came to America, at the beginning we faced some challenges, because of the new place, the new country, and the new culture.
At that time, there was a very well-established community in Chicago, within our Ismaili community. There is their volunteering system. It helped us a lot.
As we had a work visa, for that reason-- when we were in Chicago, we liked it very much because after Pakistan it was our second home, but from there because of work we had to move to New York,
and because of the rules and regulations as well.
Moving here, we faced more challenges, because [I think] New York is a very expensive state,
the most expensive city in the world.
For that reason, one should really work hard. We are not as relaxed as we were before, now we have to work hard.
Well, the challenges were to find an apartment to live closer to our community, a proper school for our child, and to continue our religious customs was pretty hard.
There is a very strong point here, that our [Ismaili] community is very united and strong, as in Chicago.
But there are more Wakhi speakers here [in New York].
There are six or seven families with their children here.
They are with their relatives here.
For that reason New York is a very good place [for us], because weekly, whenever we all want, we get together and sit together.
So, whenever we gather together even our children use the language, follow the culture, and it enables us to be closer and united.

There is a famous Wakhi poet Bulbul Nazir, who is my favorite poet, and he always mentions, and our elders and my father always say that, if you don't speak your own language with your children... the problem of our language is that Wakhi language has no written form, it is not written.
So the only way [of saving the language] is to teach it and talk to our children.
We should tell them stories, and tell them good words so that they get close to [the language and culture].
At the same time, they will know their own language.
But everyone is like us when we go abroad, the [way of life] in the family changes.
Because when we live with our parents-- when we go to another country we live far from them and from our relatives-- so in terms of that, one faces challenges.

Apart from this, if parents don't pass on their language [to their children] and tell them that our language is not in use and that only knowing English is important... that the other language is good and will be used in the child's studies,
that is the way the language will disappear in an instant.
As Bulbul Nazir says about language,
he also has a famous [saying] that if a language disappears, the whole culture ends.
If a culture dies, the whole history will ends.
So up till now, we are trying to pass the language on to our children, in order to keep it and develop it.
